SEARCH
Package model

Class Grid

java.lang.Object
model.Grid
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class Grid extends Object implements Serializable
Represents the 2D board (grid) for the Gomoku game. Manages the placement of pieces, neighbor connections, and alignment checks. The grid is initialized as a square matrix (default 15x15). After each move, the grid updates directional neighbor links between pieces. Provides alignment-checking logic for win conditions.
Since:
2025-03-26
See Also:

  • Field Details

    • grid

      private Piece[][] grid
      The 2D array representing the game grid. Each cell can hold a Piece or be null if empty.

    • size

      private int size
      The size of the grid (number of rows and columns). The grid is square.

    • serialVersionUID

      private static final long serialVersionUID
      Serial version UID for serialization compatibility.

    • Grid

      public Grid()
      Constructs a default 15x15 grid.

    • Grid

      public Grid(int size)
      Constructs a square grid of the given size.
      Parameters:
      size - the number of rows and columns (square)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the size is not odd
      IllegalArgumentException - if the size is not positive

  • Method Details

    • placeTheFirstPiece

      public void placeTheFirstPiece(int i, int j, Piece piece)
      Places the first piece on the board. Should be placed at the center of the grid.
      Parameters:
      i - the row index (should be the center row)
      j - the column index (should be the center column)
      piece - the piece to place

    • placePiece

      Parameters:
      piece - the piece to be placed
      row - the row index
      col - the column index
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the cell is already occupied

    • isAdjacentToAnotherPiece

      public boolean isAdjacentToAnotherPiece(int row, int col)
      Checks whether the given cell has any adjacent non-null neighbors.
      Parameters:
      row - the row index to check
      col - the column index to check
      Returns:
      true if at least one neighbor is occupied; false otherwise

    • fivePiecesAlligned

      public boolean fivePiecesAlligned(Piece piece, int alligningNum)
      Checks whether the specified piece completes a winning alignment.

      It verifies if the piece is part of a straight line (horizontal, vertical, or diagonal) containing at least alligningNum consecutive pieces of the same color. The method searches in 4 direction pairs (LEFT+RIGHT, UP+DOWN, and both diagonals), counting how many pieces are connected in both directions starting from the given piece.

      Parameters:
      piece - the newly placed piece to check alignment from
      alligningNum - the required number of consecutive pieces to win
      Returns:
      true if the alignment condition is met, false otherwise

    • countInDirection

      public static int countInDirection(Piece piece, Direction dir)
      Counts how many consecutive pieces of the same color are connected from the given piece in the specified direction.

      Traverses the chain of neighbors in that direction using Piece.getNeighbor(Direction) until it reaches a piece of a different color or a null neighbor.

      Parameters:
      piece - the starting piece
      dir - the direction to count toward
      Returns:
      the number of consecutive same-colored neighbors in that direction

    • countSameColorInDirection

      public static int countSameColorInDirection(Grid grid, int row, int col, int color, Direction dir)
      Counts how many consecutive same-colored pieces exist from (row, col) in the specified direction, scanning the grid directly without relying on neighbor links.

      This method is intended for use by the AIPlayer to evaluate potential moves. It does not require the piece to be placed or linked into the neighbor structure, making it safe for hypothetical simulations.

      Parameters:
      grid - the game board
      row - the starting row (position of simulated piece)
      col - the starting column (position of simulated piece)
      color - the color of the simulated piece
      dir - the direction in which to count
      Returns:
      number of consecutive same-colored pieces in the given direction

    • wouldAlignWith

      public boolean wouldAlignWith(int row, int col, int color, int winLength)
      Chooses the next move for the AI player based on the current game state. This method delegates to the dynamic version using the player's configured winLength.
      Parameters:
      row - the row to simulate
      col - the column to simulate
      color - the color to simulate (0 or 1)
      winLength - the number of aligned pieces required to win
      Returns:
      true if the simulated move would result in a win, otherwise false

    • getPiece

      public Piece getPiece(int row, int col)
      Retrieves the piece at the specified row and column.
      Parameters:
      row - the row index
      col - the column index
      Returns:
      the piece at the given position, or null if the cell is empty or out of bounds

    • isGridFull

      public boolean isGridFull()
      Checks whether the grid is full (no empty cells).
      Returns:
      true if full, false otherwise

    • getSize

      public int getSize()
      Returns the current size of the square grid.
      Returns:
      the number of rows (and columns)

    • inBounds

      public boolean inBounds(int r, int c)
      Checks whether the specified row and column coordinates are within the boundaries of the game grid.
      Parameters:
      r - the row index to check
      c - the column index to check
      Returns:
      true if (r, c) lies within the grid bounds; false otherwise

    • expandGrid

      public Grid expandGrid(int newSize)
      Creates a new grid of a larger size, copying the existing pieces to the new grid while maintaining their relative positions.
      Parameters:
      newSize - the new size for the grid (must be greater than current size)
      Returns:
      a new Grid object with the specified size and copied pieces
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the new size is not greater than the current size or not odd

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Returns a colored, well-formatted, and coordinate-labeled string representation of the game grid.

      This method visually renders the entire board using ANSI-colored ASCII symbols:

      • X: Black stone (Player 1)
      • O: White stone (Player 2)

      The grid is surrounded by row and column numbers on all sides for player orientation. ANSI escape codes are used to color:

      • Row and column numbers: Red for columns, Blue for rows
      • Player pieces: BrightBlack for Player 1, BrightWhite for Player 2

      Alignment is dynamically maintained for single- and double-digit coordinates. Works best in terminals that support ANSI escape sequences.

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      a string representing the current grid state with borders, coordinates, and colored pieces

    • modifyNeighbours

      private void modifyNeighbours(Piece piece)
      Updates the neighbor references of the given piece in all 8 directions.

      For each direction, if there is an adjacent piece on the board, this method links the given piece to it using setNeighbor, and vice versa. It ensures bidirectional connectivity between adjacent pieces.

      Parameters:
      piece - the piece whose neighbors are to be updated
